Name: Finger Twister Game
Description:
This is a game in Daiso's Joint Party Series of games. 
Players place their figures on a small board according to the outcome of spinning a special spinner, which indicates a spscific colour and the finger which must be used to touch a spot with that colour on the board. 
Players who are unable to do so lose.

This is a different game from the game called 'Finger Twister' in the BGG database. This game uses all five fingers (unlike Finger Twister) and the board has a different arrangement of spots and also includes special spots known as 'breathless points'.

The instruction under 'breathless point':
"You can touch whom you are interested in through the delicate balance position! Sometimes physical contact bring people together."

However, there's also a caution on the label: "Please note that this game doesn't always let boy meets girl."

Name: Prezyun Breake
Description:
Translated from the manual:

A prison. It's where the shit jerks who did too much are put.
A place where the rats who were either stupid or clumsy are kept separated from society until they cool down.
No one, no matter how crazy, wants to go there.
But there was one complete idiot who ended up in the special prison for violent maniacs.
...and that's you.

It's defended by a system that Alcatraz or Bastilles don't come near. A huge hell, finely constructed and full of patrols.
If you can get out of there, the next thing and you'll be able to break of out Hell itself.
Even so, this is your line:
"So what. I have to do it."
You have to, to save the guy on death roll, who was innocently judged.
Use your skill, your genius and your brains to the fullest.
What awaits you is unimportant. Your must save the man, get him out of there, think tactically, and use whatever tools you can get ahold of.
Got it? Good. Let's get going.

Name: Le lapin malin
Description:
Contents: a board with the drawing of a circuit with circles and rabbit holes. 8 rabbit pawns. 36 carrot pawns. 2 dices.

The goal of the game is to be the first to pass the arrival line.

Each player chooses a rabbit, and receive 5 carrots. Rabbit move accordingly to the result of the dices thrown. One can choose to throw one or two dices, in the latter case he must pay a carrot (if he makes a double with the dices, he get his carrot back). The circuit have special circles such as “carrot”,  “coyote”, blue or pink circles, each  with special actions to be make.

Name: Death at Samarra
Description:
In Death at Samarra, you must protect your Servant while stalking your opponent's pieces. But which piece is his Servant, and which is Death? Your Merchant can reveal another piece's identity, but in doing so, unmasks himself.

This two-player game of bluffing and hidden strategy plays quickly, but uniquely each time. How well can you outguess the person across the table?

Download the two-page black-and-white PDF DeathSamarra_ed1.pdf at the Files Section, print and assemble it in 15 minutes, and play several 3-8 minute games with a friend tonight.

Name: Kapitú
Description:
A Trivia type of game, played in teams (2 to 4 teams - 8 max. per team).

The goal of the game is to name the maximum correct answers in one minute. Sample questions are: "In one minute name all the birds you know, for example seagull". Team members start, in order, naming birds. If one of the members repeats an answer or makes a mistake, the teams loses and only the previous answers count.

The board is used to advance in difficulty, and the game ends when the first team reaches the final box. Corrects answers are then added and the team with the highest score wins.

An 18xx game set in the Osaka metropolitan area of Japan.

Rules are available as Wiki at http://www.boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/1890_English_Rules

Name: 1899KP
Description: An 18xx title that covers the Korean Peninsula

Name: Tumble Logs
Description:
From the box: "Stack your logs on the pile in 45 seconds without letting any of them tumble and you score!"

The game includes three dice, a 45-second sand timer, and wooden "logs" of three different sizes and colors.  On a player's turn, they roll the three dice.  The color and number of each die tells how many logs of each color must be added to the stack.  The player has 45 seconds to add them without wrecking the stack or having any logs roll off.

Name: Història Màgica de Catalunya
Description:
[EN]: A simple fantasy-medieval game in which the player must travel around Western Mediterranean cities (specially Catalan ones) with the ultimate aim of dueling with and defeating a mythological dragon. During the travel, the player gets cards in each city he passes, and these cards drive the game, as they contain events, missions, travels and so on, which can improve the player's powers until he or she is ready to fight the dragon.

---

[CA]: Un joc simple de temàtica fantàstica-medieval, en què el jugador ha de viatjar per diverses ciutats de la Mediterrània occidental (especialment catalanes) amb l'objectiu final de lluitar i véncer un drac mitològic. Durant el viatge el jugador rep cartes a cada ciutat per la qual passa i aquestes cartes dirigeixen el joc, ja que contenen esdeveniments, missions que cal complir, viatges, etc. i permeten millorar les característiques del jugador fins que està llest per lluitar amb el drac.

---

[ES]: Un sencillo juego de tema fantástico-medieval, en el cual el jugador tiene que viajar por diversas ciudades del Mediterráneo occidental (especialmente catalanas) con el objetivo final de luchar y derrotar a un dragón mitológico. Durante el viaje el jugador recibe cartas en cada ciudad por la que pasa y estas cartas dirigen el juego porque contienen eventos, misiones que hay que cumplir, viajes, etc. y permiten mejorar las características del jugador hasta que está listo para luchar contra el dragón.

Name: Game of RIO
Description:
RIO is a fast paced, light family card game which acts superbly as a filler.

What makes the game special is that it comes in the Parker Brothers standard box size of its time, same as e.g. Star Reporter.
Thus it is completely oversized, but if it's your cup of tea you are rewarded during gameplay by excellent graphics on the board and the box inlays where holiday scenes are depicted.

Game consists of 48 cards - 4 sets of 12 numbers in 4 colours - which have to be laid out in a given pattern onto the board where a kind of discard-clock is shown.

In order to win you have to get rid of your cards before all other players.

You can score in different ways, and you have to decide when it's the best time to lay out your own or to destroy opponents winning combination and when to exchange cards of your hand with pre-dealt cards on the clock.

Although the rules state that 3 to 6 can play it also works well with 2 players, and there are variants for partnership play.

Name: TEE-RIVIA
Description:
TEE-RIVIA

Golf Trivia Game

(c)1994 DSH Enterprises

"A game for those who love golf, its rich history and its colorful heroes."

Players compete as individuals or teams as they move around a game board representing an 18 hole golf course answering trivia questions about golfing.

Includes 1200 questions on 400 cards, 6 playing pieces, dice, rules, and board.

Ages 14 and up.

Name: Take it Away
Description:
Take it Away was published in A Gamut of Games. A word by Sid Sackson:
"Take it Away is the name of the game and not, I hope, the verdict of the reader. Compared to Focus and Network, which demand extreme concentration to be played at the highest level, Take it Away can, and should, be played in a relaxed manner."

Take if away is based on Solitaire but is designed for up to four players. It uses a checkers board and poker chips in different colors. The first player take the first chip and creates a hole in the board, then the play continues with each player doing a solitaire-like move. Each chip captured counts to that player score, different colors have different values.

Any player can give-up playing at any time, except the last, that must continue play until no more moves are allowed. This last player has a penalty to his score based the chips remaining on the board.

Name: Hold that Line
Description:
Hold that Line was published in A Gamut of Games, a word by Sid Sackson:
"If all people who played Tic-Tac-Toe were laid end to end they would promptly fall asleep. That's is the kind of game it is. Yet put two people together with a pencil, a scrap of paper, and some time to kill and chances are they'll wind up playing endless games of Tic-Tac-Toe, with never a winner.
"Hold that Line is a game I devised to fill just such an odd moment. It, too, is played with a pencil and a scrap of paper, but there is a chalange and a winner in each and every game."

This game is played in a dotted grid similar to that of Dots and Dashes, but the objective is not to control boxes inside the grid, but to not be the last player drawing a line in the grid. Each line must be straigh and each player must play on either end of the line draw. The entire line must be continuous, without branches, crossings or a dot being visited twice.

Name: Cutting Corners
Description:
Cutting Corners was published in A Gamut of Games.

On a piece of paper, draw a square with two adjacent sides one color, and the other two sides the other. Each player will use a color. In your turn, a player draws a line that starts in one side of the square, do a right angle, and end in another side of the square. The first player start by doing this without further inplications, then the second player must cross one line already in the square, then next play must cross two lines, three lines, four lines and finally five lines, after that the game end with the original square divided in various sections. Each sections is won by the player that was more sides in it. Winner is the player who takes most sections.

Name: Paper Boxing
Description:
Paper Boxing was published in A Gamut of Games.

Paper Boxing simulates a boxing fight with a grid of 4x4 squares and numbers. Each player makes his grids with an S (for START) in the upper left square and completes with numbers from 1 to 15 the others in any way he wishes and in secret. Then they both reveal their grids and the first player, from the S, moves to any other adjacent square in his grid. The other player does the same. Whoever ends in the highest number won the round. The player winning the first round starts the second round. Play continues like this and if the numbers are the same, the two players have a tie. If one of the players is left without moves before he can move the entire grid, he loses by KO. The player who won the most rounds wins the game.

Name: Last Word
Description:
Last Word was published in A Gamut of Games, a word by Sid Sackson
"Last Word was born one day when I was stranded with two word-game lovers far from any letter cards, letter dice, or letter tiles. Challenged, I devised a game using only an available pencil and some sheets of paper. I was rather surprised when it gained a considerable measure of popularity among my friends, some praing it as the "last word" in word games."

Last Word is played in a grid on squares 9 x 9. The central 9 squares are filled with 9 letters at random. In his turn, each player puts a new letter adjacent to at least two others already in the layout. Using this letter and the others that are in line with it, the player forms words. The letters can be rearranged in the layout to acomplish this. He can not put a letter if he can not form a word in at least two different direction and he scores by multiplying the lenght of all words formed by that letter. It is not necessary to use all letters in a direction, but all letters used must be continuous up to the letter added.

The game ends when all four edges of the grid are reached with at least one letter.

Name: Property
Description:
Property was published in A Gamut of Games.

This game is played with an 8x8 squares grid and a deck of common cards. Also, each player have some money at his disposal.

The cards are divided, being the numbers used to determine coordinates (black are the lines and red the columns)on the grid and the figures to represent buying power of the players.

In his turn, a player plays two cards corresponding to a coordinate in the grid. If that square is empty, he take possession of it, if that square belongs to another player, he must pay a rent to that player, and after that, has a chance to buy that square with his figures cards. If the square is him own, he mortgage that square. If a square is mortgaged twice, that player loses its possession.

Game ends when a player can not pay a rent. The winner  is the player with most money, properties are not considered.

Name: Change Change
Description:
Change Change was published in A Gamut of Games.

In this solitaire game, the player takes eleven coins: four from each of two different denominations, two from a third denomination, and one unique. They are arranged randomly in a 3x4 layout, with an empty space in the bottom-right.

The player aims to transform the layout into one that is symmetrical around the horizontal axis by sliding the coins (like a slide puzzle), counting each slide as a 'move'. The usual target is to complete 7 rounds in less than 100 moves.

Name: The No Game
Description:
The No Game was published in A Gamut of Games, a book by Sid Sackson.

"As promised, here is The No Game. This is not one that I created myself, though I wish I had. It is a great party game, taking fifteen minutes to prepare, one minute to explain, and as much time to play as the guests wish to devote to it."

It is a very simple party game in which each player receives a ribbon. When a player makes another to say 'No', he can take all ribbons from that player. The game continues until a predetermined time, when the player with the most ribbons is declared the winner.

Play is as follows:


         Locate a nice prize.
         As everyone enters the party, pin a small ribbon on their clothes, one per person.
         After everyone has arrived, gather them together and give a speech similar to the following:
             “The object of tonight’s game is to collect the most ribbons. To collect ribbons, you must have an opponent say the word ‘No’ to you. Upon uttering that word, you may promptly collect every ribbon currently pinned on them; they are yours, at least until you say ‘No.’ Other words, phrases, and actions, like ‘Nah,’ ‘Certainly not,’ and a swift slap, are perfectly valid; only uttering the word ‘No’ causes a lack of ribbons. At [some time here], the person with the most ribbons wins the game, and receives a nice prize.”
        
         Play as the speech above states.

Name: The Simpsons Board Game
Description:
The object of the game is to win!

Winning the game varies depending on which character you are playing.

If you are Homer, you win the game by saving enough money, 750 Bucks, to buy a new (well, nearly new) Cadillac Convertible. Then you must get back home by an exact dice roll.

If you are Marge, you win the game by saving enough money, 750 Bucks, to afford a day in health and beauty farm including hairdo, beauty make-over and manicure. Then you must get back home by an exact dice roll.

If you are Lisa, you win the game by saving enough money, 750 Bucks, to buy a real pony. Then you must get back home by an exact dice roll.

If you are Bart, you win the game by saving enough money, 750 Bucks, to buy a giant Krusty the Clown Robot, a Radioactive Man, skateboard, a deluxe catapult, a spy camera, a jiffy squirt ring, a Space Mutant Video Game, anty-gravity boots and a real tatto. Then you must get back home by an exact dice roll.

Name: Seawolf: A Game of Submarine Combat
Description:
The third game in the "Great Little Game Line" (#7003).

"A Game of submarine combat"

From the box: Exciting WWII submarine wolfpack versus convoy action. Can the wolfpack sink or turn back the convoy? Can the convoy's escort ships thwart the attacking submarines and get the convoy to safety with needed supplies? Seawolf features a tactical playing board, with full sized hex pattern, cut counters, rules booklet and printed score sheets.
Families: Series: The Great Little Game Line (Grenadier)

Name: Ringo
Description:
Ringo is a two-player abstract strategy game said to be from Germany. It was likely invented sometime in the late 1800's or early 1900's. Pieces are captured similarly as in checkers, but no multiple jumps are allowed. Thought to be descended from the Tafl group (Fox & Geese, Tablut, Hnefatafl).

The game simulates a castle siege. Attackers are attempting to enter a castle (the center circle on the board) while defenders are trying to protect it and reduce the number of attackers. Since the attackers out number the defenders, the defenders have an advantage in movement.

Name: Succe$$ Quest
Description:
(From the box cover)

Game Concept:

A game designed to allow Players to learn or teach business concepts and strategies in an enjoyable, competitive environment.

Players match wits with the business logic of the game's creators.  While discussions of questions and disagreements can ensue, the creators provide the logic behind their answers.

Players may have to "agree to disagree" to win - but no one "loses" if they enjoy learning the realities of the business world that have worked for the game's creators.

Name: Pele's Perils
Description:
From the publisher:

This fun, educational game teaches about the Hawaiian culture and the hazards of living on a volcanic island.

Pictures and arrows show the way to go UP by sharing goodness with others, and the way to go DOWN because of the dangers of the volcano.

When a player is lucky enough to meet Pele (peh-leh), the goddess of fire, she will uncover a secret passage through a lava tube to the top of the volcano.

But, you must be careful! If you get caught in the middle of a lava flow, you may need to be rescued by a helicopter!

Good luck and mahalo (mah-hah-lo) (thank you) for spreading lots of aloha (ah-lo-hah) (love).
The first player to reach Pele (peh-leh) at FINISH is the Winner!

Name: Ohana Mana
Description:
From the publisher:

This fun, educational, game teaches about the Hawaiian culture and the strength of the family, as well as the dangers of living on a volcanic island.

Throughout the game, Hawaiian words are followed by the pronunciation and the definition of each word in parenthesis to assist the players in learning about the Hawaiian culture. (Additional notes regarding the pronunciation of Hawaiian words are provided at the end of the game book.)

Each player has a 4-member 'ohana (oh-hah-na) (family) that they move around the board. Along the way, players gain mana (mah-nah) (spiritual energy) by doing good deeds to spread aloha (ah-loh-ha) (love), encountering cultural and geological sites, and answering questions about Hawai'i.

When two members of the same family meet on a space, they form a Family Bond which no player can pass unless they have enough mana (mah-nah) (spiritual energy). If a player has enough mana (mah-nah) (spiritual energy), they can also capture other players and send them back to Start. However, there are many environmental hazards which will keep players from reaching the top of the volcano. Therefore, players must be very careful not to collect too many kapu (kah-poo) (danger) cards!.

Good luck and mahalo (mah-hah-lo) (thank you) for spreading lots of aloha (ah-lo-ha) (love)!

Name: Wąż
Description:
WÄ…Å¼ ("Snake" in Polish) is a 2-player connection game with moving tiles played on a 7x7 square grid.

The rules are simple and elegant: Each player has square tiles in their own color.  In turns, they add a new tile to the board pushing it in from an edge and pushing the entire row as far as it will go until all the tiles in that row are collected in a contiguous line touching the opposite edge of the board.  At the middle (4,4) square of the board is an immovable wall which also blocks pushing.  The goal is to create a continuous connected set of tiles in your color which connects opposite sides (either north/south or east/west).

Name: Imperial Guard II
Description:
Imperial Guard II is a set of fast-playing Napoleonic era miniatures rules, for use with 15mm or 25mm miniatures.

The rules are supplied in a 25-page softcover digest format, in a ziplock bag, with 3 letter-size combat charts.

This is a sequel to Little Soldier Games' 1976 effort, Imperial Guard.

Name: Manifesto Destiny
Description:
A historically refined revision of the game Manifesto.

The game is played on a map of the world divided into twenty regions. The components also include a custom deck of cards, consisting of Conflict Cards and Influence Cards.

If there are four or fewer players, the players choose to play one of the four standard ideologies: Communism, Fascism, Socialism, and Revolutionary Capitalism. If there are more than four players, three additional ideologies are available: Fundamentalism, Anarcho-Syndicalism, and Nipponism.

The players represent ideologies in conflict in the 20th century. The game begins in 1925 and ends in 2025. Twenty rounds are played, each representing five years. The winner is the player who controls the most countries at the end of the game.

Name: Battle Dice: Quests & Artifacts
Description:
An expansion for the game Battle Dice.

Each turn a players has the option of sending their Infantry, Archer, and Mage dice on a quest. If the questing forces survive by destroying or routing the units they encounter, the questing player receives a random artifact.

There are twenty types of artifacts, ranging from simple caches of gold (used for hiring units) to magic wands, orbs, scrolls, and weapons.

Name: On Spec
Description:
ON SPEC is a round game based on the buying and selling of stocks and shares.

Cards consist of "share cards" and "quotation cards".
Share cards come in the commodities of Rails, Rubbers, Oils,
Gold, Motors and Shipping and are beautifully printed coloured chromo-lithographs.
Quotation cards are less spectacular and show numbers in red and black for "up" and "down".

Following the game rules you can speculate in rise and fall, trying to find the best moment to buy or sell.
Stock price is adjusted by central play of the cards of the stockbroker player.

Play money are little coloured bone chips.

Nice little time-witness game with outstanding components quality.

Name: Long Hop
Description:
Long Hop is a betting/dog racing game.
It consists of a large, colourful canvas playing mat, an ordinary deck of 52 cards and 4 cardboard greyhound dogs wearing the card colours heart, spade, diamond and club.

The dogs are moved via a clever card drafting/setting system which is also enhanced by special orders depicted on the race track. These are triggered when the dog(s) pass the spaces.

Game ends after 6 races, richest player wins.

Name: HipBone Games
Description:
"The HipBone Games are board games in which players link one fact or idea with another, claiming points for each link."

The game is played on a board made up of ten spaces connected to one another by lines. A variety of boards with varying layouts and connections are available. Current boards include Psyche's Board, Tenstones, WaterBird, Pentagram/Mercedes, and Circuit Board.

Players take turns writing "ideas" into vacant spaces on the board. In competitive play, players score points "by claiming links between the idea in their own move and the ideas already in play in those positions on the board connected to it by the lines of the board in question. A link can be any form of association - similarity, opposition, cause-and-effect, metaphor. Fanciful links may be made and enjoyed - or hotly contested."

"The HipBone Games are based on the concept of the Glass Bead Game described by Hermann Hesse in his Nobel-winning novel, Magister Ludi. They are foremost among current attempts to bring Hesse's game concept into implementation."

Name: Rapunzel
Description:
Players race to be the first to rescue Rapunzel by climbing up her hair.  To do this, players actually climb on the side of the board to Rapunzel, who is sitting on the top.  The board depicts four of Rapunzel's braids, one for each player.  Players advance up the side of he board by drawing colored tiles that are sitting face down.  Each tile pictures the game's hero, a prince, with two different colors in the background.  The first tile for each player is placed without restrictions, one color on the bottom and the other on top, but subsequent tiles must match the color facing up on the previous tile.

Players alternate choosing tiles from the face down pile.  If they cannot place the tile, they return it after everyone has seen it.  There are also witch tiles for use in a version of the game for older children.  If a player draws a witch, all other players are forced to discard face-down the tile at the top of stack.  The first player to rescue Rapunzel twice wins.

Name: Go Fish the Board Game
Description:
As suggested by the name, Go Fish the Board Games uses the basic mechanics of the card game Go Fish.  Players each select a color and the goal is to collect all three of the fish matching that color.

At the start of the game, all the fish tokens are placed face down in the middle of the board.  Each player picks one fish token to begin then, in order, players spin and spinner.  If the spin results in a "Go Fish," the player selects a fish token from the middle of the board.  If a number is spun, the player moves on the board and takes the action on the space.  There three actions: "Go Fish" where a player selects a piece from the middle, "Shark!" where a player must put a fish back in the middle, and "Ask!" where a player can ask another player for a fish.  If a player is asked for a fish and doesn't have it, he tells the other player to go fish.

The game ends immediately after one player collects all three fish of his color.

Name: Fighter Pilot
Description:
Fighter Pilot is a World War II aerial combat game utilizing metal fighter plane miniatures. The rules feature historically-accurate aircraft capabilities and fighter pilot ratings.

Consists of a 32-page softcover digest.

Name: Holiday
Description:
Object of this game is to accumulate sightseeing points.
1st player to earn 2500 is the winner, each world tour is valued a certain number of points.
Players gain or lose points on tours, enjoy opportunities or encounter adventures.
The action is transfered from the globe right to 8 different tour tracks.
Other game components are:
-4 Passports
-5 different kinds of Money in different denominations
-30 Adventure Cards
-4 Landmark tokens
-1 Currency converter
-1 High-Quality dial Spinner
-1 Distance and Travel Cost Computer

Although Replogle's Holiday is in fact a simple Roll-and-Move-Game it's still fun for the family, as you have to funnel out your routes with the "Travel Computer" and to wheel and deal with your different currencies.

The colourful 1950ies artwork of the components add to the atmosphere of gameplay.

Name: El Dorado: Game of the world's hidden Treasures
Description:
Game hails from the heydays of Parker Brothers Company regarding their game components quality and design. On the other side this is a nightmare for game collectors, as the box measures 20×14×2 inches. Add a gameboard twice its size, other game components and both box halves made of ultra-thick cardboard, a book containing all the game's treasures of the world and their descriptions and last but not least metal game pieces, and you have a game weight of over 3 kg.

Gameplay is simple but fun for the whole family. Out of nearly 100 cards you get a random set of 5. They show the treasures you have to find and to dig out. You travel one of the numerous routes on the board depicting a world map to reach your destination as fast as possible. In order to do this there is a clever system how to use your dice roll. When you reach your destination you take 2 special dice, pay the digging fee and try your luck.

To enhance your treasure income, you can choose whenever you want to unearth one of the nearly 50 additional pirate treasures. But destination is hidden, and if luck is not on your side, you have to travel round the globe to reach it, and you are not allowed to skip it!

Game ends when the first player reaches home port after his last treasure of the initial 5 has been lifted, but winner is the one with the most income.

Highlight of the game are the pawns: Tiny little petroleum lanterns made of metal in 6 different colours.

Parts Inventory:

2 d6 of various sizes/types of the day
2 special red lucite dice with zeros on four sides
6 lantern movers large or small
64 or 65 black cards
30 red cards
20 $500    chips
30 $1,000  chips
30 $5,000  chips
30 $10,000 chips
10 $50,000 chips

Name: Galaxy Trucker: The Big Expansion
Description:
From BoardgameNews.com:

Spiel '08 will see a new truckload of interstellar destruction with Galaxy Trucker: The Big Expansion. As is often the case with expansions, The Big Expansion includes a number of mix-and-match components:


     Pieces and rules for five-player games.
     An updated version of Rough Road Ahead, a set of cards previously released in a downloadable format on the Czech Games website that will be expanded and reformatted.
     Additional adventure cards, including two previously available only at Spiel 07.
     A special deck of adventure cards that players individually insert into the deck themselves to surprise their fellow drivers.
     A new alien species.
     New ship building components, including life support for the new ET.
     New ship classes.


The expansion is not fully compatible with the first edition of Galaxy Trucker, due to component differences. A compatibility kit has been produced, containing replacement components for the base game, but as of March 2009 it is not yet widely available.

Name: Brainiak
Description:
"A mind blowing team game ... with no wrong answers".

Two teams compete to work around the board, avoiding headaches and migraines, maximizing brainwaves.  Each team is asked a challenge questions eg "Name five types of cake", and secretly writes their answers.  Points are awarded for common answers, allowing each team to move around the board to victory.

Name: Sense-Ation
Description:
From the box:
Can you correctly identify a candy by taste?  An onion by smell?  An egg by feel?  Too easy?  Try identifying the sound of a person walking without shoes by hearing?  Estimate within one inch the height of someone by sight?  Or guess the content of a picture by ESP?  Wait until you try the Wild Cards, which give you a chance to invent your own challenge to stump your opponent.

The object is to collect points to advance to the 'Finish' block on the game board. Points are collected by correctly identifying objects using the senses if sight, hearing, touch, taste, smell and the 'sixth' sense, ESP.

Name: Hero Pax 3: Jungle Heroes
Description:
Fighting in the Pacific Theater of WW II. Each of these scenarios contains a hero. These scenarios feature American army and marine, Japanese, Australian, and Dutch Marine forces. The action takes place in Saipan, Java, Luzon, New Guinea, and the Admiralty Islands.

Sequentially following the Hero Pax numbering, these scenarios are numbered HP 17-26.

Contents:
10 scenarios

Hero Pax 3 is not a complete game. Ownership of components from the ASL game system are required to play this game. This scenario pack is compatible with the ASL Gaming System (ASL) by Avalon Hill / MMP.

Name: Pygmies on the Pirueti Plains
Description:
You lead a smallish warband of Pygmies, in scraps against other Pygmies. The Pygmies are distinguished by the
colour of their feather plumes. There are for instance the Redfeathers, constantly bickering with the Bluecrests.
But you can colour the feathers any way you want, and make up your own names.
This game can be played in one of two ways:
Either as one shot games, where you start with a warband made from the army list. Or you could make a
campaign where you harvest the jungle and steal from other warbands as a way to improve your own warband.
The rules that are used are the Flat Out War by Oversoul Games at www.oversoul-games.com

Get the Game here:
http://www.oversoul-games.com/oversoul_download.html

Name: Primosole Bridge: ASL Journal 6 Historical Module
Description:
Primosole Bridge is a historical module for Advanced Squad Leader that appeared in ASL Journal 6.

The Primosole Bridge was a key bridge on the Sicilian coast near Mt. Etna which the British required, intact, to continue their drive along the coast. They dropped airborne elements to seize the bridge and wait for their ground forces to arrive. The problem was the Germans also realized the importance of the bridge, and landed their own Fallschirmjaegers nearby to hold the bridge and reinforce the Axis units in the area. With both sides having crack troops on hand the battle was fierce with the British nearly collapsing when their ground troops finally came to their rescue.

Contents include a full color 20.5" x 30" map, 20 pages of campaign specific rules (Z39-Z58), 3 campaign games, and 3 scenarios (J95, J96, J97).

Name: Port 'N Starboard
Description:
From online description:

Simple, yet realistic, fun board game that employs the principles of sailing and sailboat racing. Visualize sailing into the windward mark on a starboard tack, calling for right-a-way at the mark, or getting a big puff downwind to slip past several boats. Play by yourself or with up to eight players. Play your own boat by starting behind an imaginary line sailing to windward, tacking to avoid the head wind, rounding the mark, reaching to the second mark and on to the downwind leg of the course. The basic strategy involves port and starboard tacking and staying clear of the competition. Fun and instructive for the new sailor and a challenge for the experienced skipper. The whole family will love to play as there are no complicated wind changes and the game moves along at a pace that will keep everyone interested. Game is boxed and includes a playing board, eight pewter boats, chance cards and dice.

Name: Kennen Sie Di?
Description:
A trivia game where players try to guess facts about famous women. One player reads an event, all others as a team try to guess the correct year. There are various special chits available for help, for example "tell year of birth" or "tell another event in her life".

English translation of the title: "Do you know Di?"

Name: Pictionary Chocolate Edition
Description: Like the classic Pictionary game. The cards are all chocolates. If someone guesses the word correctly, the person drawing gets to keep the chocolate and the person who guessed it gets to draw.

Name: Circus
Description:
The aim of the game is to find the Ring Master.
Each player is a small clown.
They turn around the ring to collect three different cards (monkey, seal, dog) to be able to enter the ring and try to find the Ring Master hidden in 7 ring cards (3 lions cards, 3 public cards and one Ring Master Card).
Players have to avoid bad square and they also can steal each other cards if the are on the same square.
The first player to find the Ring Master wins.

Name: Tschikago
Description:
This is a dice game in Barti's range of match-box sized games (Art. 3606).

The game comes with 3 wooden dice and 6 red wooden pawns that are called 'bottles'. The first player rolls the 3 dice and has up to 3 rolls to get a score that he/she is satisfied with. Ones count as 100 points, sixes as 60 points and other numbers of pips are face value. A player can stop before using all 3 rolls. Subsequent players now have the same number of rolls to roll a higher score. If a player fails to roll higher than the previous high score, the player has to take a bottle and a new round begins. When all the bottles are taken, the rules change - a player now puts back a bottle in the middle if someone is unable to beat their score. The loser is the last player left to hold any bottles.

Name: Empire
Description:
Empire is light civilization-building game, played using 4 shared decks of cards.  In that respect, it bears some similarity to games such as San Juan or Race for the Galaxy, but with added combat and resource-development elements reminiscent of Magic: the Gathering.  The game, the first offering by fledgling publisher Gurushar Games, provides 2 to 4 players six different paths to victory: either by amassing 80 Gold (a measure of the civilization's wealth), 30 Order (a measure of infrastructure and governmental improvements), or 10 Support (a measure of the civilization's morale).  Alternatively, a player may attempt to reduce their opponent's Gold, Order, or Support to 0, thus eliminating them from the game.
Similarly to Magic: the Gathering, Resource (i.e. land) cards, such as farms or villages, are played, and then taxed to produce Gold.  This Gold is then spent to play more Resources.  It is also possible to use this Gold to buy Units (which defend the land, or can attack an opponent's Order), or Systems (e.g. Democracy, Capitalism, Martial Law), which provide permanent upgrades to a player's capabilities.  Alternatively, your Gold may be spent to trigger 1-time Event cards, or simply hoarded to reach the 80-Gold victory condition.

Name: Operation: Darkstar – an Ambush Alley Scenario Pack
Description:
In conjunction with Ambush Alley Games, Rebel Minis is releasing OPERATION: DARK STAR.

OPERATION: DARK STAR contains an exclusive mini-campaign written by Ambush Alley!

The campaign consists of three interlocking scenarios revolving around a Task Force Black mission that begins as a simple hostage rescue and culminates in a desperate battle to prevent the release of a biological agent in Baghdad's Green Zone.

This is a pdf booklet that can also be purchased as an attachment to "Operation: Dark Star Battle Box", that contains the 15mm miniatures to play the scenarios.

Expands:

    Ambush Alley! A Game of Modern Urban Combat

Name: Geek Fight
Description:
Geek Fight takes place in a convention setting where you, the Geek Fight player, might run into a hairy anime character wearing thigh-high boots and an ill-fitting sports bra moments after being detained by a Stormtrooper demanding to see your credentials. You can also expect to encounter any and all of the stereotypical convention characters, vendors, swag, items, and crazy events that appear at conventions, or "cons."

Geek Fight has already seen its second release with the help of the Angry video Game Nerd and the Nostalgia Critic, with a third release coming around the bend.

Due to the fact that the production of the cards is partially funded by advertisements from other geeky companies as well as the lack of a randomized packaging element, Geek Fight is one of the most wallet friendly games in the CCG (with that first "C" meaning customizable and not collectible) market today.

Geek Fight: All of the Strategy, None of the Bankruptcy.

Name: Snakes and Ladders of Life
Description:
Snakes and Ladders variant for children with the addition of virtues and vices in each square. "A virtue at the top of a ladder is what you gain as a result of applying the virtue at the bottom of the ladder in your actions and behavior" (eg enthusiastic --> tireless; loving --> accepting). Similarly a vice at the head of a snake results in the outcome at its tail (eg argumentative --> isolated; worried --> tired).

A booklet accompanies the game that defines each virtue/vice in one sentence simply understood by a 7 year old.

Some squares allow the player to draw from the 'Virtue deck'. "These cards describe how a virtuous attitude can rescue you from the karmic payback  for hurtful, negative attitudes."

The final variation on the traditional game is the last eight squares called the Safe Zone, which allow the player to draw from the 'Power Deck' of cards. "On reaching this zone of the 8 Powers you are safe under their canopy, protected from all negative influences, because an inner voice guides you away from situations which steal your energy. In this zone you enjoy strength, good fortune and happiness."

A score pad is included that encourages each player to write down each of the virtues that they accumulate during the game.

The material does not appear to be specific to any one religion.

Name: Gem Thieves
Description:
One night only!. That's all the time the invaluable MacGuffin Gems will be on display on the Metropolis Museum. As one of the top four thieves in the city, you've prepared for months to infiltrate the museum and steal the Gems. Now that you're inside the museum, you not only need to sneak from the guards, but also dodge the other thieves' attempts to spoil your plans.

Sneak your way to the Gems while trying to catch your opponents in this simple stealth tile game.

Thanks to Massimiliano Cuccia, now the Italian translation of the rules are available.

Want a copy? send an email to memegamestudios@gmail.com (only copies in Spanish available).

Name: Football Resurrection
Description:
Football Resurrection is a collectible trading card game based on Association Football (Soccer). It combines card collecting and trading with game play that requires both strategy and skill.

Two players go head to head in a game of football, with each directing their own personalized team. Through collecting uniquely designed footballer character cards, each with their own special skills, players have a limitless choice of strategies and tactics so no two games are ever the same.

Play centres on taking alternate turns to build your footballer character cards into attacking and defending moves whilst the footballer character special skills enable you to enhance your moves or disrupt your opponents.

There are no restrictions placed on formations or style of play. You can pick a team of bruisers with special skills like "Body check" and "Thundering tackle" or try to cheat your way to victory with "Covert cynical tackle" and "Diver cheat" or play the classy way with "Playmaker" and "Attacking pace" or blend them altogether.

It's a language-level2 game as play centres on the text on the cards, although once payers become familiar with their cards this text is seldom used.

The first release of cards is entitled "Hell In The Pacific - The Unity" and includes 81 unique footballer character cards from 40 countries. These first edition cards may be hard to come by as the publishing company is rolling the game out through Hobby stores, Bookshops and Football Club Shops in the UK on a regional basis.

Further releases of cards "New Blood" and "The Final Conflict" which increase the number of strategic and tactical permutations are scheduled for 2009 and 2010.

Home Page: http://www.footballresurrection.com

Name: Wizards and Warriors
Description:
Wizards and Warriors is a collection of five fairly simple games all set in a generic fantasy environment. The game was published in a fold-out cardboard folder on which the five different boards are printed. Contained within are the rules booklet and a counter sheet. The boards and components are illustrated by Cathy Wood.

The Wizard's Chamber (2-4 players)
Simple roll-and-move game with set collection.

The Curse of the Tomb (1-2 players)
Basically a race game, where one player controls an adventurer  and the other player controls the tomb and deploys hazards.

Escape from the Troll King (2-6 players)
Roll-and-move race. First player to reach the end of a long cave tunnel wins. Monsters pop in and out of caves along the way and act as obstacles.

The Mines of Aslok (2-6 players)
Basic roll-and-move movement, where the first player to escape the Mines with treasure wins. On their way out they need to evade traps and fight demons.

The Vault of Illusion (2-6 players)
More dynamic and complex game, compared to the others. The adventurers move across a multicoloured hex grid at random, dictated by a coloured spinner. The goal is to acquire a magic weapon and then battle one of six different monsters.

Name: Padok
Description:
objective: To gain points by placing the pieces on certain formations.

Players throw the dice and can place a piece on the sector of the same color. Points are granted if certain figures are formed. The Padok name refers to the central square.

Name: 3D Memo Smurfs
Description:
Can you remember who is hiding where? Join Papa Smurf and all his friends in a fun game of hide and seek! Flip over a card and find the matching figurine underneath one of the five cups. There’s more than one of each card so you still have a chance to find it’s match…even if it’s already been won by another player! It’s all the fun of classic memo…and more, in an easy to learn 3D game.

Available in Spain, Italy, France, Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Belgium, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg.

Name: Cube
Description:
Cube is a modular game based on famous Cube film trilogy. The Cube is a prison formed by cubes that can contain deadly traps. Your goal is to take out prisoners from the Cube prison avoiding trap cells that have different levels of danger. Once on top of the cube they must find an exit.
Players can move 1 or more peons or you can play solo game. In every cube you get a card: it can be an event or an object card. Events must be played immediately; object cards can be saved for further use, and could help to safe your life.

There are different ways to play; you can also play using characters with advantages and handicaps. All information and necessary files can be found at :

http://cube.nafarroa.org/index.php?&loc=en_EN

Files:
http://cube.nafarroa.org/filez/cube.en/cube.en.zip

Name: Package has Arrived
Description:
A game designed by the famous Israeli writer Ephraim Kison, describing the bureaucracy around receiving a package from the Israeli post office in the late '60.

Players roll the dice, advance their markers on the board and follow the instructions while collecting all the necessary documents.

Name: Finish Lines 2
Description: A set of 500 new cards for Finish Lines. It uses the same categories in the base game and is not a stand alone edition.

Name: Die Biene Maja: "Willi, wo bist du?"
Description: Maja is looking for her friends hiding under the flowers but Thekla the Spider is lurking about.  Can Maja find her friends before finding Thekla?

Name: Busy Train Memory Game
Description:
From the Box:

"From fun with a frog to a pirate at the party - there's a new surprise to find behind every window of the busy train...but will you remember where you saw it?

How to Play:  First fit the two engine pieces together, then add the carriages/cars.  Now fit the window pieces face down, at random, into the spaces.  Shuffle the cards and place the pack face down between the players.  Players take turns to turn up a card from the top of the pack and then "open" a window.  If the window matches the card, the player leaves the window open and keeps the card.  If not, the player must close the window and return the card to the bottom of the pile.  When all the windows have been opened, the player who has collected the most cards is the winner.  For a shorter and simpler game, play with fewer carriages/cars and take away the corresponding number of window and memory cards.

Contents:

5 thick train pieces
15 window pieces
15 memory cards

Educational Value:

A wealth of detail encourages observation
Develops concentration and memory

Play Value:

Amusing illustrations stimulate imagination and add to the fun
Increase the challenge by adding carriages /cars"

Another well done memory game for kids 3+

Name: Tales of Arabia
Description:
An Arabian themed storytelling game.

"Goal of the game: Being about to tell and finish stories... The longer the story, the more victory points will be earned..."

The stories and sub-stories must be based on cards played by the players. The game ends when one of the players has been able place a final ending to the main storyline.

Victory is determined by scoring the most points. Points are awarded based on finishing story lines and on the number of story cards the player played.

Name: Cloudburst
Description:
From the Game Box:

"An exciting and unusual colour-matching game which encourages sharing and co-operation."

This jigsaw/game includes two sets of rules, one for a cooperative game and one for competitive play.

Players take turns rolling a die which either adds pieces to their house (player mat) or to a central 'cloudburst' mat.

The object of the game is to complete your house before the cloud bursts!

Name: The King's Caste
Description:
The King's Caste is a modified Tarot deck that was designed to answer this question: What if European Chess were a card game?
It is compatible to any Standard Card game, or Tarot Card game, yet there are subtle differences that allow for wider range of game play/design.

The 86-card deck contains the following:

     16 cards in each of the four French suits (spades, hearts, diamonds, and clubs):
         10 numbered cards:
             8 pawns (value 1–8, #1 is hashed)
             2 bishops (value 9–10, #10 is hashed)
        
         6 face cards:
             2 rooks (one hashed)
             2 knights (one hashed)
             1 queen
             1 king
        
    
     22 trump cards
         I–XXI
         0

Name: Multi Test 6000
Description: A Trivial Pursuit-like game in Spanish. Same mechanics with cheaper components.

Name: DICE Boxing
Description:
DICE Boxing is a downloadable game from Gen1400 Gaming.  You get over 1,000 boxers from the 1800s to today in over 10 different weight classes.  More boxers are also available for free download.

Every boxer is rated in numerous categories based on their real life statistics.  Boxers will perform in DICE Boxing just like they do in the ring.

Replay super fights or create your own league and or tournaments.  How would Ali have done against Marciano or Mike Tyson?  Pit any two fighters against each other.

DICE Boxing also has a career mode.  Create your fighter and earn points by winning fights and moving your way up the rankings.  Do you have what it takes to become a champion?

DICE Boxing uses everything from ring movement to strategies.  DICE Boxing can be played with the simple basic game version or add more options to the advanced version to get a simulation close to real life.

Name: DICE Racing
Description:
DICE Racing is a downloadable game from Gen1400 Gaming.  All you need is two 10-sided dice.

You get over 50 drivers from the 2007 Nascar season.  Each driver card is based on their real life statistics.  Each driver will perform in DICE Racing like they do on the track.

DICE Racing also has a career mode where you create your driver and as you perform on the race tracks you will earn more points to improve your driver.

You can replay the entire 2007 Nascar season or you can pick and choose which drivers you want to use and create your own season.

Name: Grace A Dice Play 21
Description:
Grace A Dice Play 21

From the rulebook:

This is an enjoyable, easy to play game for children and adults at home, school, churches, parks, casinos and sports fields.

Even teams of up to 6 people are formed.  Plus a 'director' manages one or two teams.  A die is rolled to indicate the movement of the player.  The player is moved on a board AND around the seating of the table.

Play alternates until one team returns the the original seating.

Name: Office Space: The Party Game
Description:
The Office Space Party Game allows four teams to compete at a variety of activities in an attempt to rule the "cube farm" at Initech. Throughout the game, each team earns Office Cards for completing party activities (Drawing, Charades, Word Hint, and Fill-in-the-Blank). If at least one team has 10 or more Office Cards at the end of any round, the team with the most Office Cards wins!

From the back of the box:

"Unable to endure another mind-numbing day at the office? Office Space, the party game based on the cult film, is a sure cure for a case of the Mondays.  2 - 4 teams compete at a variety of fun activities in an attempt to rule the 'cube farm' at Initech.  Teams frequently change their position in the office hierarchy, taking turns abusing their authority."

Name: Conundrum
Description:
The Mind-Bending Anagram Game

The mental work-out for grey matter! Part anagram puzzle, part charades contest, this game tests you and your team-mates as you seek to solve a tricky set of conundrums. Each player takes a turn, assisted where possible by other team members. All scores combine into a grand team total. Many hours of fun packed into a handy pencil box!

Name: Pumpking
Description:
The old Pumpkin King has recently passed to the great beyond. 
there is a battle  being waged between his two heirs for control of the patch. Who will take the throne?   
 Pumpking is a 2 player abstract strategy game that was inspired by the ancient game Latrunculorum. 
Players face off on a grid 6 squares wide by 11 squares
long. Each army consists of a Pumpkin Prince, two bats and six pumpkin warriors. The three pieces move following different rules.

Name: Quiz Royal
Description: Players have to try to answer as many questions as they can by traveling through a town.

Name: Paper Cricket
Description:
Paper Cricket was first devised by Luke Morris in 1993 as a child trying to pass the time on long car journeys. With the rules written down for the first time, Paper Cricket is now available, for free, to everyone.

Paper Cricket is a simple game that aims to provide a bit of entertainment if you’re stuck as a passenger on a very boring car/train/plane journey or when you’re stuck late at work with nothing but some paper, a pencil (or pen) and a dice. At its’ most simple you need nothing else.

Paper Cricket does NOT intend to perfectly simulate the ebb and flow of a cricket match BUT from experience it does enough to provide realistic scores, averages and statistics. Cricket, like baseball, is a game of statistics.

With simple play rules (and optional squad selection mechanics) it's a game to pick up and play wherever you are and whatever you're doing.

Name: Carcassonne: The Cult
Description:
This small expansion contains 5 tiles, each showing a picture of a Cult. (Cults are comparable to Cloisters). When a Cloister and a Cult are adjacent, a challenge begins. The player who first encircles his tile gets 9 points, the other player gets nothing.

Part of the Carcassonne series.

Name: Allo... Docteur?
Description:
The goal of the game is to be the first doctor to correctly diagnose the illness of the patient.  This is achieved by a process of elimination.

The components are the best part of this game as it comes with a complete set of diagnosis tools and a patient.

Name: U Dubopoly
Description: This is your typical fund raising Monopoly. This one is set at the University of Washington, known by locals as "U Dub" rather than U of W.  The University of Washington is in Seattle.

Name: Don't Call us...We'll Call You
Description:
"Don't Call Us..." is an exciting peek into the complexities of the world of entertainment.  You compete with one or more players to be the first to win the five "points" of the Game Star, OR to earn $1,000,000 as an actor.  You prepare for jobs in the industry by taking lessons, getting 8x10 glossy pictures, joining the Screen Actors Guild, finding an Agent, and so forth.

Box measures about 6 1/4" x 4 3/4" x 2 1/2"

Name: Duel of the Sun Slayers
Description:
This is a tactical space combat game in the Warriors of the Dark Star: The Age of the Neutron Wars series, and includes the second edition rulebook for that game (as a series rulebook).

From a GFG catalog (reproduced verbatim):


        This "WD" Game pits the powerful Omega Ship Constitution Class against the Deadly Unruk Dreadnaughts of the N'Dridds and the Sumnul Betas. Scenarios such as the "Attack on the Outposts", "Seige of the Frontiers", "Plunder Raids of the Brain Slaves", etc. This is a detailed comparison of what occured in the BFA "Deliverance from Beyond the Stars".


 

        Geomorphic Map—Sections, Hardbacked, solid boards, each one 11x14 inches, can be combined into a 22x28-inch mapboard, or a 44x14-inch, 64x11-inch mapboard, or any other combination. The Boards here have 9 different kinds of Space Obstacles and Vortexes. The amazing thing about WD boards is that the four boards in this game can be connected to the mapboards of other WD games, and ALL WD GAMES have their boards so made that they can be interconnected with all the other WD versions. Counters are on 8 1/2 x 11-inch large sheets showing the weapons systems in detail that the silhouettes on the BFA counters only implied. THIS GAME CAN BE PLAYED BY ONE OR MORE PEOPLE (UP T0 11 can play). Each player handles one ship. Sun Slayers specializes in OutPosts, Beacons, Omega Ships, Monitors; all are enclosed and utilize the drama of the long-term duties of the Star Forces in the  defensive OutPosts that might be raided at any time to poke a hole into Federation territory, for Taal Battle Cruisers to rush through and how fast Thetan and Alliance ships can rush to the aid of the Defensive Line.

Name: Sahara Sandstorm
Description:
"Colonial Era Combat game: 1879 - 1929. French Foreign Legion, British Colonials, Germans SWA Troops, etc. Simple, fun wargame rules for backyard, beach or living room."

"The romantic tales of the French Foreign Legion, the drama of the hundred British regulars who held off 4,000 Zulu warriors at Rourke's Drift, the harsh battle of Khartoum - these are the stuff of legend. Sahara Sands is a fast-action battle game that enables you to replicate those days of tropical heat and adventure. You bring the toy soldiers, regular dice and kite string while we show you how it's done!"

Ratings are provided for seven types of weapons common to figures of this era: rifle (rolling block or bolt action), jezail (muzzle-loading rifle), revolver, spear, cannon/mortar, Gatling gun, and machine gun. Each weapon is rated for rate of fire, range, and damage.

Basic unit speeds are provided for different types of units and vehicles (foot soldiers, camel troops horsemen, wagons, tanks, trucks, etc.) Terrain effects on movement are also specified. The rules also cover officers/leaders, prisoners, forts, and the shock value of 'modern' weapons.

Name: Tanegashima Sandman
Description:
"Samurai Combat Rules. The excitement and action of 16th Century Japan. You are a daimyo leading your personal army against your rivals. Armed with spearmen, ninja, gunners and your elite Samurai warriors, your forces bring the battle to the enemy!"

"These simple rules make for a fast, fun game with plenty of action.  Play on the beach, in the backyard or living room. Adaptable to almost any scale, from HO to 12" action figures."

Figures are divided into four classes: Light Spearmen, Medium Armored Troops, Samurai, and Ninja. Weapons are divided into seven classes: pole-arms, small arms, samurai swords, thrown weapons, archery, muskets, and lances. The game includes rules for hand to hand combat, missile combat, terrain effects, armor effects, sieges, and campaigns.

One of the Jersey Shore Battle Games, available for free online

Name: Treasure of Sandheap
Description:
"Pirate Adventure Game. These is a very simple game for play on beach or in backyard, with plastic toy soldiers. The focus is on a fast-action game, easy to learn and easy to play. Our game is for small battles, only - with forces of 100 men or less on each side."

There are fourteen types of characters specified in the rules. These include pirates ("the heroes of our game"), tow militia, the Navy, Marines, Moors, Conquistadors, Privateers, Indians, South Pacific Natives, and Samurai.

There are seven types of ranged weapons specified in the rules: Long Rifle, Pistol, Musket, Bow, Cannon, Light Cannon, and thrown weapons (spear, hatchet, tomahawk, marlinspike, etc.) Each weapon is rated for range, damage, and rate of fire.

Concepts covered in the rules include boarding, prisoners, ports, treasure, and the effect of tides and wind on boats. Campaign suggestions are also included.

One of the Jersey Shore Battle Games, available for free online

Name: Planetary Sand
Description:
You command a task force of galactic troopers against enemy forces on distant planet. Your Planetary Infantry, supported by Space tanks and all-atmosphere personnel carriers, take on the opposition on desolate asteroids, bizarre planets and far-off space stations. Your troops are armed with the latest particle bean cannons, ray guns and zap rifles in their quest to make the Universe safe for Humanity

A simple, fun game for kids of all ages. Play it on the beach, in the backyard or the living room rug!

Three battle scenarios are presented: an open field battle with two forces facing off across No Man's Land, an assault on a defended position, and a battle in which each side is attempting to capture and hold an objective on the opponent's side of the field.

Units are rated for movement, attack range, and damage (at close, medium, and long range). Range and damage ratings vary based on whether the battle is located in a vacuum ("Space Atmosphere") or in a "Half-Earth" setting.

The rules also cover missiles, grenades, terrain effects, defensive armor, air supply and robots (divided into seven types). Advanced rules add spacecraft, planetary facilities, communications, and leadership. The advanced rules also prsent more distinctions between vehicles (wheeled, tracked, hovercraft, etc.)

Name: Muskets and Sandpiles
Description:
"Rules for American Revolution and the Alamo. These is a very simple wargame for play on beach or in backyard, with plastic toy soldiers. The focus is on a fast-action game, easy to learn and easy to play. Our game is for small battles, only - with armies of 100 men or less on each side."

"We have taken into account such things as flintlock pistols and the differences between muskets and rifles. (In this era, rifles could not be fitted with a bayonet! Only muskets had the bayonet attachment!)"

The players must supply the appropriate toy soldiers. The rules divide the figures into five types: Infantry (foot soldiers), Cavalry (mounted soldiers), Artillery (gun crewmen and cannons), Rangers (infantry with rifles), and Indians (who fight as infantry or cavalry).

Each type of figure is rated or movement, as are wagons and caissons. Six types of ranged weapons commonly found with Revolutionary War miniatures are rated for range, damage, and rate of fire. Other concepts covered in the rules include terrain effects, hand-to-hand combat, walls/bunkers, forts, and soldiers fighting as units.

Name: Sandarticus
Description:
A game which pits Roman legionnaires against a variety of adversaries. Sandarticus is a simple, fast-paced game of small-unit action in the Roman Empire. Roman soldiers defend the Empire against enemies from without and within. Fun, exciting, easy to play, for all ages.

Several different troop types are defined in the rules: Roman Legionnaires, Roman Cavalry, Roman Auxiliaries, Greek Hoplites, Greek Light Infantry, Gladiator Revolutionaries, Revolutionary Auxiliaries, Gauls, South Germans, and North Germans. Units are ranked for speed and armor.
 Twelve types of personal weapons and three siege engines are described and ranked for damage and range. Advantages and limitations of certain weapons are also specified. Other concepts covered in the rules include leadership, formation fighting, and mercenaries.

Name: Castle Cracker
Description:
"Medieval and Ancient Warfare. A simple, basic game based on warfare in ancient times. Easy to learn, easy to use, for backyard, beach or living room. Uses almost any size or type figures, from plastic toy soldiers to collectible miniatures."

The figures are divided into a variety of classes: Infantry (with distinctions based on level of armor), Cavalry (light and heavy), Charioteers, War Wagons, Siege Crews, Archers, and Hakenbuschers (including Arquebusiers and Musketeers).

Each type of figure is rated for movement and each type of weapon is rated for range, rate of fire, and impact (at short, medium, and long range).

Basic castle siege rules are included. Advanced rules cover formations and morale, as well as offering further distinction to various historical units and projectile weapons.

Name: Operation Sandtrap
Description:
Rules for Toy Army Soldiers. This is a simple, easy game for play in the backyard or on the beach. Our goal is to make it fast, fun, enjoyable and cheap.

The players must supply at least thirty toy soldiers per side and any heavy weapons or vehicles (tanks, APCs, half tracks, artillery, etc.)

Each type of weapon (rifles, mortars, grenades, flamethrowers, etc.) is rated for range (long, medium, and short), shots per round, and damage. Explosive weapons are rated for their damage radius. Vehicles are rated for armor (front, side, and rear) and speed (road, off road, and steep/rough ground).

The rules also cover terrain effects and scenario types.

Advanced rules add leaders, radiomen, minesweepers, obstacles, bridges, morale, and concealed movement.

Name: Jersey Shore Battle Games
Description:
"The Jersey Shore Battle Games [previously known as the Sandy Hook Battle Games] are a group of simple, easy-to-play miniature battle games developed for one purpose: FUN! Unlike conventional board and miniature games, Jersey Shore Battle Games dispense with complexities altogether. Our goal is to provide a game that can be set up and played spontaneously, without studying complicated rules or spending extra money for expensive miniatures. Everything has to be commonly available."

The components required for play are kite string, two six-sided dice, a sand pail, a cup, a disk segmented into quarters (i.e. lines marked on a paper plate), and the appropriate toy figures.

The basic system rules are available for free.

The following games use the Jersey Shore Battle Games rules system:


    Castle Cracker
    Muskets and Sandpiles
    Operation Sandtrap
    Planetary Sand
    Sahara Sandstorm
    Sandarticus
    Sandpit Showdown
    Tanegashima Sandman
    Treasure of Sandheap

Name: Rabbidgerbal's Colonials -vs- Martians Steampunk Miniature Game
Description:
"The great behemoth landships with coal fires stoked and steam boilers at full pressure chub their mighty pistons, sending vibrations of fear shaking the ground and hearts of men."

"Landships are the tanks of H. G. Wells imagination and the main figures in this game, One per side along with 4 (5-10) man infantry squads, Gatling gun, and a cannon crew of two men, or limits of your imagination... as you experiment with more squads and/or landships in larger battles."

"The enemy of our Victorian Era heroes armed with steam and black powder? Martians! These are Martian's not of -war of the worlds- level tech, but who grasp ‘like’ ability weapons they may have a co2 powered bolt weapon or Martian water pistols (to be cool) but just use 'musket' stats."

Name: Rabbidgerbal's Biplane Dogfight Game
Description:
A miniatures air combat game based around the author's rudimentary homemade biplane miniatures which use a plastic soda bottle-cap as a base.

Movement is measured in inches, with the distance moved based on the roll of one to four six sided dice. The basic planes move 2d6 inches each turn. The number of dice or distance rolled will be modified if the aircraft dives, turns, or performs special maneuvers (stall, climb, barrel roll, or loop).

Combat is resolved by the attacker rolling machine gun dice and the defender rolling maneuverability dice. For the basic planes, each player rolls 3d6, with a hit being scored if the attacker rolls a higher total. A plane is shot down after taking six hits.

Advanced rules cover gun jams, sun position, rear gunners, custom planes, pilot skill levels, and damage effects.

Variant rules suggestions are included for Star Wars dogfights.

Name: Sandpit Showdown
Description:
"Rules for Wild West and Civil War. These is a very simple wargame for play on beach or in backyard, with plastic toy soldiers. The focus is on a fast-action game, easy to learn and easy to play. Our game is for small battles, only - with armies of 100 men or less on each side."

The players must supply the appropriate Cowboy and Indian or Civil War toy soldiers. The rules divide the figures into four types: Infantry (foot soldiers), Cavalry (mounted soldiers), Artillery (gun crewmen and cannon), and Indians (who fight as infantry or cavalry).

Each type of figure is rated or movement, as are wagons and caissons. Each of the weapons commonly carried by these types of figures is rated for range, damage, and rate of fire.

Other concepts covered in the rules include terrain effects, hand-to-hand combat, walls/bunkers, forts, prisoners and escapes. Scenario suggestions are given for open field battles, defense of forts, and relief of besieged forts.

One of the Jersey Shore Battle Games, available for free online

Name: Wiz-War: Expansion Set #2
Description:
From the bag:

"This set has 85 new cards featuring "Artifacts". new tokens, and new rules, with the "Mad Wizard" (a listing of rules and card arguments) and a very short story: "The Legend of Wiz-War". You will need Expansion Set #1 for Monster and Magic Stick rules.

"Note! This set is only valid for 5th edition and earlier Wiz-Wars!"

Most of this material never appeared in the Chessex editions.

Expands:

    Wiz-War

Name: The Great Crusade
Description:
The Great Crusade is a roll-and-move game which starts as a puzzle and a big cardboard castle/tower. The players construct the board by putting together the puzzle, and then roll-and-move to see who gets to the dragon's hiding place first.
The Castle constitutes the game box, and the whole package is called The Enchanted Castle Adventure Play Set. Included are rules for "The Memory Game", using the cards and tokens.

Name: Miliard w rozumie
Description: Game based on Polish TV show. Players roll a die and move their pawns on the board. Different locations on the board indicates different categories of questions. We have science, nature, art, humanities and others. In some situations players must take part in a knowledge duel. After correct answer player gain money and moves his/her pawn forward. If he/she doesn't know the answer, moves backwards or pay the fine.

Name: Ticket to Ride: The Dice Expansion
Description:
In this expansion for the Ticket to Ride series, players still attempt to complete their Destination Tickets and claim routes and block each other on the map. But rather than draw and collect Train cards, they roll five custom Train dice each turn.

Depending on the outcome they can re-roll some or all, then use the dice to claim routes on the board; grab Route Tokens for future use; or draw more Destination Tickets.

For board maps that feature Tunnel routes, such as Ticket to Ride: Europe, 3 Tunnel dice are also included.

This expansion requires trains, Destination Tickets and a board map from any of the Ticket to Ride series.

Name: Atom Smasher
Description:
When particle physicists compete for grant money, they usually do it with proposals and plans. But this time around, a lunatic angel investor has asked you to prove yourself worthy of his full support by competing on a different level: the atomic level. He has gathered the world's most capable physicists to demonstrate their prowess with a particle accelerator, using it to carefully and precisely chisel off subatomic particles from a huge atom.
Overview

Players take turns flicking or sliding a small opaque pyramid (called the smasher) into a cluster of pyramids (called the atom). Each pyramid which is smashed a sufficient distance from the atom scores points equal to its pip count for the player.

Name: Spider
Description:
Spider uses a system of movement and jumping similar to that of Chinese Checkers, but with a twist.

The first playing piece (or 'fly') to cross the "Goal Line" at the other side of the board becomes the Spider and is placed in the center of the board. On subsequent turns, the Spider player may move the Spider in addition to their normal move.

Once the spider has collected a number of flies equal to the number of opposing players, the Spider is returned to its place at the opposite Goal and another player may become the spider simply by being first to move a fly into the center of the board. Captured flied are returned to their starting spaces when the current Spider 'retires'.

Another difference is that movement (and jumping) around the Spider's lair in the center of the board may be made in either direction.

Play continues until one player succeeds in moving all of their flies past the opposing Goal.

This odd game was published in Ocean Beach - a community of San Diego, California.

Name: Home and Away
Description:
From the box:
"Who broke the church windows?  Who sank Alf's boat?  Your friends at Summer Bay are being blamed for a series of nasty acts but they are innocent.  Can you prove this?
Go around the game board as quickly as possible chatting with the Summer Bay characters.  They know the facts that will help you solve the mysteries."
Based on the Australian Soap Home and Away this is a variation on the classic Clue(do) and The Mysteries of Peking.

Name: Severiano
Description:
"Super Juegos" was a pioneer Spanish magazine about both, board and computer games, which was published between 1984-1985. Every issue included a board game inside, with rules and cut-out counters. As far as I know only eight numbers were published, at least in its first epoch (another publication with the same name would appear years later, this time focusing on computer games only).

"Severiano" (named after the famous Spanish golf player Severiano Ballesteros), was included in issue 2 and was obviously a golf match simulation. Players had to provide two counters (representing balls) and two dice, plus pencils and paper to note scores. Dice rolling determine the movement of the counters, while several terrain features affect movement in different ways.

Name: Canguro
Description:
"Super Juegos" was a pioneer Spanish magazine about both, board and computer games, which was published between 1984-1985. Every issue included a board game inside, with rules and cut-out counters. As far as I know only eight numbers were published, at least in its first epoch (another publication with the same name would appear years later, this time focusing on computer games only).

"Canguro" (Kangaroo) was the game included in issue 1. It was a very straightforward game in which players, who had to provided the counters, tried to align these from the inside to the outside of the circle in the board.
